elements.value: Who created this platform and why?

The IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation has designed and structured this collaborative storytelling and knowledge sharing platform to increase the visibility of information and data generated in collaboration with the expert conservation community in the region in recent years.
What kind of information can I find in this platform?

You will find a combination of authoritative maps with narrative text, images, and multimedia content based on publications and reports edited by IUCN-Med in collaboration with other key stakeholders in the region. We are also accepting relevant examples from other regional stakeholders for publication so that this platform becomes a dynamic collaboration space.
All maps are available for download and may be harvested by other geoportals as long as the source is mentioned.
How can I use this platform?
In addition to reviewing data and downloading/sharing it, this platform is open to other organizations that wish to share geo-reference information on Mediterranean biodiversity conservation.
You can submit a story by sharing a map, text and uploading images, video, or web links.
Contact us for more details.

cover.name: Cover
cover.title: Do you know where the most beautiful Mediterranean diving secrets are?
cover.subtitle: Mediterranean coralligenous environments

elements.value:
The coralligenous environment is one of the most typical Mediterranean underwater seascapes.
These colourful landscapes can be found growing on a variety of locations and at depths ranging from 20 to 200 meters.

They are also known to be one of the most important habitats in the Mediterranean because they can offer shelter and subsistence for many forms of marine life, and are considered important for fisheries and carbon cycling.

Today, these habitats are mostly being degraded and threatened by pollution (e.g. wastewater discharge from the coast) and various bottom fishing techniques and gears that increase the re-suspension of sediments and affect the species living on it.

The spread of exotic algae, climate change (increasing and unusual fluctuations of seawater temperature) and frequency of storms are also known to affect several key species that occur on these environments.
The designation of Marine Protected Areas and specific measures to improve water quality and limit fishing activities should help protect these submarine gardens.

credit.footer: © Seaphotoart
credit.author: Dreamstime.com

elements.value: Figures

The coralligenous is considered as the second benthic ecosystem in the Mediterranean and host 1700 species, among them 1300 algae, 1200 invertebrate species, and more than a hundred fish species. It also holds up to 48% of endemic algae species.
From 2013-2016, the European Red List of Habitats examined the extent and status of all the benthic marine habitats in the different European Seas including the Mediterranean.
Among them, the decline observed of coralligenous habitats in their extent and quality make them to be classified as Near Threatened in European seas.

credit.footer: European Red List of Habitats, EIONET

elements.value: Conservation curiosities
Coralline constructions are considered hotspots of biodiversity and are extremely popular among divers.

They are mainly produced by the accumulation of calcareous encrusting algae growing and shaping unique formations where a rich associated fauna flourish under poor light conditions. In overhangs and big cavities animal communities of suspension feeders are dominated by different corals, sponges and bryozoans.

Coralligenous formations with species like the gorgonians Paramuricea clavata, Eunicella verrucosa and Astroides calycularis, and of course the precious Red Coral (Corallium rubrum), are Mediterranean treasures that form part of our heritage.

Indeed, it is worth considering that some of these ecosystems are estimated to take several thousand years to be built, as in the case of the constructions of Lithophylum algae in Sardinia, which constitute real natural monuments.

credit.footer: Red coral (Corallium rubrum) in the coralligenous Sardinia, Italy.
credit.author: © WaterFrame | Alamy Stock Photo

info.title: Infralittoral biogenic habitats in the Mediterranean - Coralligenous bioconcretions

elements.value: Coralligenous habitats are reported to occur primarily in the northern part of the Mediterranean basin, with few records from the eastern or southern basin where there is very limited knowledge.
In March 2008, the countries in the Barcelona Convention adopted an Action Plan to protect these important habitats.
The benign climate, gastronomic variety and various cultures inhabiting the area attract millions of visitors each year to the Mediterranean shores.

Its peoples, largely depend on the sea, as it provides them with food resources, fantastic beaches, cleaner air, jobs and a millennial connection for transport and travel among others.  However, what keeps the sea alive is not always on view: marine habitats like coralligenous in this case, are essential for the survival of many marine species, but also for people’s living. It is therefore critical to protect and promote a healthy marine environment for them to maintain the Mediterranean as we know it today.

To reverse the current degradation of these environments, we need to join forces from several sectors in a concerted effort to protect their locations against pollution, malfishing practices and the spread of invasive species.. This should include a better design and enforcement of management activities, particularly for artisanal and recreational fisheries to help prevent the depletion of target fish and crustaceans with new quotas, control of users and surveillance and compliance of fishing regulations in these environments.
Hence that measures such as further data collection and monitoring, new regulations and the protection of important areas are being promoted.
Because our marine gardens and forests take a long time to grow, but very little to be destroyed…

In fact, one of the most beautiful habitats in the Mediterranean are coralligenous gardens, where trees are replaced by soft corals (gorgonians) and flowers give way to calcareous red algae and animals such as sponges and bryozoans. These wondrous places support a high biodiversity, and steps are now being taken to better protect them

Oceana comments on the Action Plan for the conservation of the Coralligenous and other calcareous bio-concretions in the Mediterranean Sea adopted by the Mediterranean states at the Barcelona Convention.

cover.title: The case of the disappearing butterflies
cover.subtitle: Mediterranean Butterflies

elements.value: Since ancient times, people have recognized the wide range of environmental benefits provided by a thriving butterfly population. In fact, visual representations honoring butterflies from 3,500 years ago can be  seen in Ancient Egyptian frescoes. In addition to their role as pollinators and food sources for other species, some butterflies have even developed their own strategies to deter predators and parasites, find mates, or overcome their host plant´s chemical defenses.

credit.footer: Plebejus hespericus, Spanish and Mediterranean endemic, listed as Least Concern

elements.value: However during the last 50 years massive changes in human behaviors have begun to change life for butterflies in the Mediterranean region, including unsustainable agricultural practices, urbanization and increased tourism visitation and infrastructure. These changes are leading to the disappearance of some of the world´s most colourful, unique, and important creatures.
A recent IUCN report revealed that 15% of the Mediterranean´s endemic butterflies are currently threatened with extinction.

credit.footer: Resource: IUCN, Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation.

elements.value: 98 species of butterflies are endemic to the Mediterranean -- that is, they occur only in the region. The majority of these endemic species are concentrated in North Africa.
Information is still needed on the geographic distribution of butterflies and the size and  reproductive trends of their populations, mostly for species south and east of the Mediterranean.

Butterflies are one of the most iconic and popular insects for many people and have fascinating life-cycles that are used in many countries to teach children about the natural world. However, in many parts of Mediterranean Europe butterflies are in decline because of changes in the agricultural system, and could be even lost if action is not taken urgently.
elements.credit: Dr Chris van Swaay, chair of Butterfly Conservation Europe

credit.footer: Maltese butterfly, South Gozo. Europe.
credit.author: Artjoms Knazevs | Dreamstime

elements.value: Conservation curiosities: Why do butterflies have scaly wings ?
Butterflies and moths belong to the order Lepidoptera. Lepidos is Greek for 'scales' and ptera means 'wings'. Their scaly wings are different from those of any other insects.

Scales play an important part in the natural history of butterflies. They enable the development of vivid or indistinct patterns to help them conceal or camouflage for mimicry and for warning potential predators. Besides providing insulation, dark patterns on wings help absorb the sunlight and assist in regulating the body temperature. Bright and distinctive colour patterns in butterflies help communicate their toxicity or inedibility, in order to prevent a predator from attacking.

credit.footer: Edge of a moth wing at about 200 times with polarizing filter. Cutout approx: 600μm x 600μm
credit.author: © Jan Homann

elements.value: Amazing animals!

• Many butterflies have taste receptors on their feet. and they can see red, green, and yellow.
  • Antarctica is the only continent on which no Lepidoptera have been found.
  • Butterflies are unable to fly if their body temperature drops below 30ºC

info.title: Butterfly species richness in the Mediterranean region

elements.value: Altogether 463 butterfly species have been recorded in the Mediterranean, and they are not equally distributed across the region. This map highlights areas with high concentrations of butterfly species diversity.

The highest level of species richness is found in mountainous areas where the diversity of microclimates favors many species adapted to different microhabitats, e.g. in southern France, the higher parts of northern Greece as well as southern Turkey.

info.title: Distribution of threatened butterflies in the Mediterranean region

elements.value: There are 19 threatened butterflies in the Mediterranean region, including 15 endemic species. This means nearly 5% of all butterfly species are threatened in the Mediterranean region, 2% are considered Near Threatened, and more than 6 % are Data Deficient according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.
In the Mediterranean, butterflies are slightly less threatened than in Europe (8%), probably because of the higher area of remaining natural and semi-natural habitats throughout the region.

info.title: Species richness of endemic butterflies in the Mediterranean region

elements.value: Altogether there are 98 endemic butterfly species in the Mediterranean region, and the majority are concentrated in the north of Africa, especially in the Rif Mountains, the High and Middle Atlas Mountains in Morocco, and the Aurès Mountains in Algeria.
There are also important zones with endemism in the southeast of Spain (Sierra Nevada and Sierra of Baza), on the islands of Corsica and Sardinia, in southern Turkey and in Lebanon.
The group of experts working in collaboration with the IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation recommend appropriate habitat management to improve the conservation status of these valuable species.
The experts also propose urgent conservation measures to safeguard this natural capital in the region by:

• Fully implementing national and international legislation
  • Developing and implementing habitat action plans in areas where butterflies are threatened
  • Prioritizing field work and data collection for Data Deficient butterflies.

credit.author: © Michael Valos| Dreamstime

cover.title: The end of the line for Mediterranean sharks and rays
cover.subtitle: Violeta Barrios, Mar Otero, Catherine Numa

elements.value: Sharks play an important role in the food chain of the oceans, but the numbers of these fishes in the Mediterranean are decreasing at an alarming rate. Beyond the global culinary demand for sharks and rays, the so called Elasmobranchs, many non-commercial species are commonly caught in nets during fishing expeditions. The northwestern part of the Mediterranean has over the years experienced an intensive increase in fishing activity, and as a result, bycatch has become a major issue.

Overfishing, accidentally or on purpose, is also contributing to the disappearance of shark and other cartilaginous species in the Mediterranean. Current counts are quite low, and the sharks and rays do not have sufficient time to mature and reproduce, so nowadays the conservation community is focused on reducing accidental catch as well as uncontrolled and damaging fishing behaviors.
Summary of the conservation status of Chondrichthyans in the Mediterranean Sea

The class Chondrichthyes is a diverse group of cartilaginous fishes, including sharks, rays, skates, guitarfishes, sawfishes and chimaeras. The most recent regional reassessment conducted by IUCN in 2016 raised a red flag on their alarming situation in the Mediterranean Sea. Of the 73 cartilaginous fishes assessed 10 years ago, there is no sign of improvement and 11 of them have seen their status worsen.

credit.footer: This table doesn not include the four vagrant or Lesseipsian migrant species that have been considered Not Applicable (NA) for the Mediterranean region.

elements.value: At least half of the rays (50%, 16 of 32 species) and sharks (54%, 22 of 41 species), currently face an elevated risk of extinction, whereas the only chimaera species (Chimaera monstrosa) is considered as Near Threatened in the Mediterranean Sea. The threat level faced by many of these species may be worse than we think as data for 13 species are still with too scarce to conduct an evaluation and they are listed as Data Deficient. This means that their status needs to be further studied in order to evaluate appropriate protection measures.

Governments need to support catch monitoring and data collection, regulate gears and establish fishing quotas and protected areas at domestic level. Consumers on the other hand need to be aware of the risk of what buying these products entails
elements.credit: Dr. Nick Dulvy, Co-chair of the IUCN Shark Specialist Group and researcher at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver.

elements.value: Conservation curiosities

The most commonly assumed feature of sharks is their supposedly fierce nature. There are even initiatives recording kills by sharks in the Mediterranean. But these species do play an important part in maintaining the balance and diversity of species in the sea. Mediterranean sharks, rays and chimaeras control species below them in the food chain helping to maintain a healthy ecosystem.

Lamniformes, the most threatened order
The Lamniformes (from the Greek word Lamna or 'fish of prey') are an order of sharks commonly known as mackerel sharks. This order includes some of the most familiar species of shark, such as the great white shark. In the Mediterranean Sea, there are nine species of sharks belonging to the Lamniformes order, eight of them listed as Critically Endangered (5 species) or Endangered (3) in the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.

credit.footer: Small spotted catshark or Dogfish, Scyliorhinus canicula, caught at fishing nets in Croatia
credit.author: © WaterFrame / Alamy Stock Photo

elements.value:
Only in the Mediterranean
Three species of rays (Leucoraja melitensis, Raja polystigma and Raja radula) are endemic, thus they can be found nowhere else but only in the Mediterranean Sea. Two of them are facing a high extinction risk.

Maltese Skate (Leucoraja melitensis):
  • Critically Endangered

Skate (Raja radula):
  • Endangered

Speckled Ray (Raja polystigma):
  • Least Concern

info.title: Distribution of Chondrichthyans richness in the Mediterranean Sea

elements.value: Historically, the diversity of chondrichthyans was greatest in the western Mediterranean Sea, particularly, in the coastal waters of Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia, which harbour between 57 and 69 species. Diversity is slightly lower in the northwest.

When overlapping Marine Protected Areas from MAPAMED, it is highlighted that on of the richest areas for sharks and rays, the Southwest of the Mediterranean, needs to increase the coverage of protected marine areas.
Marine Protected Areas can offer the opportunity to regulate human activity in a way that benefits Chondrichthyans and local people.

info.title: Distribution of Data Deficient Chondrichthyans in the Mediterranean Sea

elements.value: In the Mediterranean Sea, up to two-thirds of Chondrichthyans may be threatened in the region, as the midpoint estimate suggests 65% of extant species for which sufficient data are available are threatened. Status uncertainty tends to be greatest along North African coasts, emphasizing the need for further research in this part of the Mediterranean region where species richness is also greatest. Although there are synoptic research surveys throughout the northern coastal waters of the Mediterranean Sea, there are no population time-series available from North African waters.The principal driver of decline and local extinction is overfishing. Most species are taken as retained valuable bycatch in small-scale and large-scale trawl and net multispecies fisheries. Historically, the number of threatened species was very high with as many as 33 to 38 threatened species found in 100 km2 cells in the coastal waters of the western and central Mediterranean Sea.

Most sharks and rays are exceptionally vulnerable to overfishing, even if accidentally, because they tend to grow slowly, mature late, and produce few offspring. Effective fisheries management is urgently needed if their populations are to recover and sustainable levels of exploitation are to be achieved in the region.

In order to address these concerns, governments should enhance programmes for catch monitoring and data collection, regulate fishing gear, and establish fishing quotas and protected areas at the domestic level. Consumer awareness campaigns should be implemented to communicate the problems and challenges related to shark products and other threatened cartilaginous fishes.
Fishermen communities should also be made aware of the potentiality of other alternative fish and assist promoting consumer’s choice.

In 2013, the European Union (EU) banned the removal of shark fins on board vessels through Regulation No. 605/2013, in order to enhance enforcement of the 2003 EU ban on shark finning (Regulation No. 1185/2003) and to facilitate shark fishery data collection.

The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) adopted a series of recommendations to invest in scientific research programmes in the Mediterranean and Black Seas. It also aims at identifying potential nursery areas and to consider time and area closures to protect juveniles of sharks and rays from fishing activities.

The IUCN Red List promotes URGENT ACTION towards these threatened species. With the use of better fishing gears and protection measures to control bycatch, some shark populations can be sustained into acceptable levels while contributing to the preservation of the whole Mediterranean ecosystem.

cover.title: How many antelope species occur in North Africa ?

credit.footer: Gazella dorcas
credit.author: © Tim Wacher

elements.value: Antelopes are among the best-known animals of the deserts of North Africa. These species have adapted to some of the most extreme desert environments in the world and they have always been celebrated for their grace and beauty in the art and poetry of the region. These species form an important part of the natural and cultural heritage of North Africa, therefore it is vitally important to conserve all of them for future generations.

Six species Gazelle family can be found throughout Africa. Many of these small, horned creatures are endangered, and their populations in the deserts, plains, and savannas of Africa are threatened due to hunting, farming, and loss of habitat.

credit.footer: Gazella cuvieri
credit.author: © Tim Wacher

elements.value: Many projects have been initiated to improve the conservation status of gazelles in the region. Concentrating conservation efforts on wild populations in their natural habitat provides the best guarantee of long-term success.
In situations where species have become extinct in the wild, or their ranges have been severely reduced, reintroductions may be the only option.
Facts
At Mediterranean level, the latest edition of the IUCN Red List (2008) shows that approximately 19% of Mediterranean known species are endangered and 1% is already extinct at regional level.

Antelopes of North Africa and those of the Arabian Peninsula are distinct species that have evolved separately.This is why it is strongly recommended that all these gazelles are conserved and managed separately in order to maintain intact the regional biodiversity and individual character of both North Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Therefore, species from both regions should neither be mixed nor diluted
elements.credit: David Mallon, co-chair of the IUCN Species Survival Commission - Antelope Specialist Group (SSC-ASG).

elements.value: Conservation curiosities
The largest antelopes of both regions, the Arabian Oryx in Arabia and the Scimitar-horned Oryx of North Africa.

credit.footer: Gazella arabica
credit.author: © Tim Wacher

elements.value: Some confusion

credit.footer: Gazella cuvieri
credit.author: © Teresa Abáigar CSIC

elements.value: These species may be both called Idmi, but they are in fact two different species. The Arabian Gazelle is the idmi of the Arabian Peninsula, while Cuvier’s Gazelle is the idmi of North Africa.

credit.footer: Resource: IUCN, Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation.
Resource: IUCN, Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation.

elements.value: Concentrating conservation efforts on wild populations in their natural habitat provides the best guarantee of long-term success.
In total, 11 species of antelopes occur: five in the Arabian Peninsula and six in North Africa.
Although well-known in a general sense, close similarity between some of the smaller species of North Africa and Arabia has led to confusion.

Conservation Strategies are useful tools to assess the conservation status of species and their habitats, and define conservation priorities. However, a main issue in Maghreb countries is the lack of experience, training and capacities for the design and implementation of Species Conservation Strategies for threatened species.
The project implemented by IUCN ‘Improving Capacity for Species Conservation in the Mediterranean Region’ tries to address these shortcomings’.

Several capacity workshops with the involvement of national authorities and some material such as a new fact sheet are helping conserve antelope species that occur naturally in North Africa and Arabia in order to preserve their genetic integrity and keep them apart.

IUCN and experts are also recommending that all these gazelles are conserved and managed separately in order to maintain the regional biodiversity and individual character of both North Africa and the Arabian Peninsula.
Furthermore, most of North Africa countries has included these species in their legislation on nature protection as threatened species.
IUCN has published Guidelines on Reintroductions (2013) that should be followed in all cases involving antelope species reintroductions and other conservation translocations in the region.

elements.value: Plants - their roots, branches, leaves, flowers and fruits, provide essential goods and services for humans and animals. They make oxygen into the atmosphere and capture carbon. They are a source of food, medicine, teas and spice. They offer shade and shelter and various habitats for many species, either big or small. Plants design the landscape, confirming crucial sceneries for the well-being of people. However, despite their fundamental role in society and a live land, not to say in the economy, important but disregarded plant areas are disappearing for various reasons, mostly because of changes in the use of land towards development.
Facts and Figure
To protect this amazing biodiversity, a conservation tool is promoted, the Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs).

The Mediterranean is in fact a biodiversity hotspot mostly because of its plant diversity. Around 10% of the world’s vascular plants (25,000) are found in the Mediterranean Basin on less than 2% of the Earth’s surface.
At the same time Mediterranean habitats have been modified and sometimes destroyed to such extent that the Mediterranean as a hole is considered a worldwide hotspot (Myers 2000).
Half of the plant species found in the Mediterranean exist nowhere else on earth.

credit.footer: To protect this amazing biodiversity, a conservation tool is promoted, the Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs). Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) are sites that contribute significantly to the global persistence of biodiversity. Since 2016, a partnership of institutions has joined efforts to agree a methodology that enable countries to identify KBAs. Through this tool, internationally important sites for biodiversity are identified using standard criteria. The following map shows the subset of KBAs identified for wild plants.

elements.value: To such an extent does nature delight and abound in variety that among her trees there is not one plant to be found which is exactly like another; and not only among the plants, but among the boughs, the leaves and the fruits, you will not find one which is exactly similar to another

credit.footer: Allium carmeli
credit.author: @Banan AlSheikh

elements.value: Conservation curiosities. New discoveries

The 2016 summer during one of the monitoring sessions at Prespa Lake IPA, volunteers of the Macedonian Ecological Society have found a rare carnivorous plant species Aldrovanda vesiculosa (waterwheel plant) that has not been sighted in this locality for over 20 years..

credit.footer: Thanks to monitoring sessions of the IpaMED project at Prespa Lake IPA (Madedonia), volunteers of the Macedonian Ecological Society have found, in August 2016, a rare carnivorous plant species Aldrovanda vesiculosa (waterwheel plant) that has not been sighted in this locality for over 20 years.

elements.value: Lessons learnt from the pilot Important Plant Areas in Egypt

As part of IPA-Med project, Dr. Karim Omar, environmental researcher and IUCN Red List Global Assessor, with the support of his team, has investigated environmental threats to the natural resources in two Egyptian Important Plant Areas (IPAs) and has provided some recommendations to address these ongoing issues. click here to go to the report.

info.title: Important Plant Areas identified to date in Mediterranean countries

elements.value: Subset of Key Biodiversity Areas identified for plants in the south and east Mediterranean. Green dots indicate the KBAs identified for plants (IUCN, 2017 in press). Most of these sites are also vital for other species such as mammals, birds, freshwater fish and amphibians.
But what can be done to halt and reverse the decline of the Mediterranean’s plants on which so much of our own well-being depends?
KNOWLEDGE

• Documentation of the status and distribution of selected plants species and habitats, including list of selected restricted range endemics and habitat distribution to be used as tool for conservation and management.
ACTION

• Include plant conservation into management actions of existing protected areas.
  • Involve a variety of stakeholder groups including civil society organizations, research institutions and public administrations.
  • Promote use of micro-reserves of flora for very restricted endemic species
POLICY

• Implement national legislation for the agreement of trade of species (Cites Convention)
  • Implement national legislation for the agreement of sharing benefits (The Nagoya Protocol on Access and Benefit-sharing)
  • Public authorities can also use Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) as a knowledge and decision-making tool to help them integrate biodiversity considerations in urban and rural planning.

The IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation and Plantlife together with scientists and expert conservationist organizations are filling the information gaps and taking action in various priority areas to help conserve Mediterranean plant diversity.

You as a scientist or as a plant conservation professional could join IUCN Mediterranean Plant Specialist Group (IUCN/SSC). If you are interested in becoming a member of on the IUCN Mediterranean Plant Specialist Group (IUCN/SSC), please contact Bertrand Montmollin

credit.author: © Geert De Knijf.

elements.value: It is not rocket science: we all depend on water, and the Mediterranean region is no exception. Yet, the availability and quality of water highly depends on the good functioning of freshwater ecosystems, such as wetlands, and on the myriad of species that play a key role in the equilibrium of these fragile and uncommon habitats.

We tend to forget that freshwater ecosystems are a precious and endangered resource: they cover less than 1% of the planet, yet are amongst the most diverse and threatened in the world. Water is a very scarce resource, and a tenth of all animal species, including half of the known fish species in the world and 35% of all vertebrates, live in freshwater.

credit.footer: Source: IUCN Red List of Threatened Species and WWF. 2018. Living Planet Report - 2018: Aiming Higher. Grooten, M. and Almond, R.E.A.(Eds). WWF, Gland, Switzerland

elements.value: Is freshwater biodiversity in a good shape?

credit.footer: Barada Spring minnow (Pseudophoxinus syriacus), Critically Endangered (CR) endemic species of the Barada Spring, in Syria
credit.author: © Jörg Freyhof

elements.value: Unfortunately, no. Freshwater species are being lost at a greater rate than either marine or terrestrial species. In the Mediterranean, based on the categories and criteria of the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species©, more than a third of assessed freshwater species are already threatened with extinction, and 13 freshwater fishes are considered to have become extinct. This is probably the tip of the iceberg, as many more species disappear before we ever have the chance to describe or assess them.

credit.footer: Source: IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ©Dragonfly icon made by Freepik from www.flaticon.com

elements.value: These alarming rates are mainly due to the loss or degradation of these species’ habitats: the extraordinary web of life in freshwaters is buckling under pressures of human development, and loss of species and degradation of habitats has consequences for everyone.

credit.footer: The Barada Spring KBA, Syria. This spring was almost completely drained in 2008 to meet the growing needs for water. As a consequence, the endemic fish species Pseudophoxinus syriacus (CR), is now possibly Extinct.
credit.author: © Jörg Freyhof

elements.value: Curiosities: the richness of wetlands

Freshwater ecosystems provide income to some of the world’s poorest communities. It is estimated that the livelihoods of over 660 million people depend on wetlands – that is, land areas that are flooded with water either all the time, or seasonally - and that 70 billion USD-worth of goods and services are at stake if wetlands aren’t preserved. In relation to freshwater fishes, in Egypt at least 378,000 people depend directly on activities related to inland fisheries and/or aquaculture, an activity that generated around 355.7 million USD in 2009. Wetlands also support unique agricultural and fishing practices, salt harvesting techniques, traditional food recipes and artisanal crafts that don’t exist anywhere else. When wetlands are lost it is the local population who bears the greatest cost, and we all lose.

credit.footer: Field surveys
credit.author: © Manuel Lima

elements.value: Freshwater ecosystems such as wetlands are also often nature’s solution to climate change, adaptation and mitigation, and a source of building materials and medicines, with an estimated 20,000 freshwater plant species currently in medicinal use.
“Protecting these habitats through site based conservation actions, such as within KBAs, can provide a powerful tool to help prevent species loss.”
elements.credit:
William Darwall
Head of IUCN Freshwater Biodiversity Unit, IUCN Global Species Programme.

elements.value: KBA, a beacon of hope for the future of the Mediterranean freshwaters

A major bottleneck to conservation of freshwater ecosystems is the lack of information on where the most important sites of biodiversity are located. One of the most successful actions to uncork this situation has been the identification of KBAs. Key Biodiversity Areas, or KBAs, are ecosystems that contribute significantly to the global persistence of species. In the Mediterranean region, a total of 376 Freshwater Key Biodiversity Areas have been identified so far. Flagging these webs of life provides fundamental information to support a wide range of decision-making contexts, end-users and international conservation efforts for the wellbeing of freshwater ecosystems, such as MedWet and the Ramsar Convention.
MedWet, Ramsar and KBAs: the case of Mediterranean wetlands

Since 1971, the intergovernmental treaty known as the Ramsar Convention provides the framework for national action and international cooperation for the conservation and wise use of wetlands and their resources.

In the Mediterranean, wetlands are rich and diverse ecosystems, and an important number of Wetlands of International Importance (Ramsar sites) has been designated in the region. Currently, there are 281 Ramsar sites, covering over 185,000 km² , which represents only between 1.7 and 2.4% of the total area of the 27 Mediterranean and peri-Mediterranean countries that are Parties to the Ramsar Convention, and around 1 to 2% of wetlands in the world.

One of the key actors of the Mediterranean wetlands landscape is the Mediterranean Wetlands Initiative (MedWet). In 2016, MedWet established a Scientific and Technical Network (MedWet STN) to enhance the implementation of the Ramsar Convention across the region and contribute effectively to the conservation and management of Mediterranean Ramsar Sites. The work of this network, organised in five working groups, focuses on five areas: climate change, inventories, ecosystem services, biodiversity and water.

Maintaining and restoring the Mediterranean’s natural wetlands and the benefits they provide to people can make a considerable contribution to helping Mediterranean countries achieve many of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),and more specifically targets 6.6, 14.2, 15.1 and 15.5, which tackle sustainable livelihoods, food and water security.

info.title: Important sites for freshwater biodiversity in the Mediterranean

elements.value:
Freshwater KBA in the Mediterranean region
In the Mediterranean hotspot, a total of 376 Freshwater Key Biodiversity Areas have been identified and proposed following the KBA standard. These sites host species such as freshwater fishes, molluscs, odonata and aquatic plants, which are key within the food webs that support wetland ecosystems.
Source: 2018 IUCN-Med and Mediterranean Wetland Observatory / Tour du Valat

Ramsar sites and freshwater KBA in the Mediterranean
In terms of area, only 15% of the total Mediterranean Ramsar sites overlap with freshwater KBAs. Out of 281 Ramsar sites found within the region, 65 match fully or partially the limits of freshwater KBAs.
Source: 2018 IUCN Med and Mediterranean Wetland Observatory / Tour du Valat

With the Mediterranean population estimated to rise to more than 500 million by 2025, the forecast is for an 18% increase in water demands, putting enormous pressure on freshwater ecosystems. Despite its tremendous diversity, its importance to people and the huge threats it faces, freshwater biodiversity is not receiving the attention and action it urgently requires.

To keep working on the protection of freshwater ecosystems, more freshwater species need to be put on the map, as IUCN has already done for Africa and in the Mediterranean. In the Mediterranean region, we particularly need to strengthen biodiversity monitoring in the southern and eastern countries, and design and implement specific and concrete short-term action plans for threatened species and their habitats across the basin. It is urgent to improve water management, especially in relation to the over-abstraction of water from springs and ground water, dam construction and pollution from agriculture and urban areas. Increased efforts are also required to control and/or eradicate invasive alien species in freshwater systems.
Out of sight, but not out of mind: we all have a role to play in safeguarding freshwater ecosystems and biodiversity.

We need to target conservation and monitoring of these critical sites, which are not receiving the attention they deserve, and particularly to the freshwater species that are most at risk, including amphibians, reptiles, fish, molluscs, plants and arthropods.

The good shape of Mediterranean freshwater biodiversity is in our hands, on bringing attention to these ecosystems and the urgent conservation action they require in order to prevent further loss in the region.

cover.title: Unwelcomed guests
cover.subtitle: Interactions and impacts of Invasive Aliens Species in Mediterranean wetlands

elements.value: Sometimes, whether accidentally or intentionally, plants or animals may be introduced by humans into an area where they  wouldn't be present naturally. Some of these species may settle down and spread. They may compete against native species, prey on them or even disrupt ecosystem processes. In the worst cases, they can end up driving native species' extinction and provoking ecological devastation. These unwelcomed guests are known as Invasive Alien Species (IAS) and Mediterranean wetlands are unfortunately also familiar with their intrusions.
Who is wetlands’ worst enemy?

credit.footer:
Source: Mediterranean Wetlands Outlook 2: Solutions for sustainable Mediterranean Wetlands, 2018, Tour du Valat, France.
Infographic: IUCN

elements.value: Wetlands are degrading and disappearing at an alarming rate, faster than any other ecosystem1. The Mediterranean region is no exception to this situation, with almost half of its wetlands having disappeared since 1970 due to a variety of pressures. Unfortunately, invasive alien species don’t play the ‘good guys’ in this plot: according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened SpeciesTM, IAS are one of the top five threats that drive species to Extinction. To the experts in this field, this is not new: IAS have meant a threat ever since 1500 A.D.2

credit.footer: Invasive species contributed to the extinction of 347 species out of 946 taxa assessed as Extinct or Extinct in the Wild in the IUCN Red List. Source: https://www.iucnredlist.org./ (2019) Infographic: IUCN. Icons: Piktochart, Threat by Smashicons, Fishing icon by surang.

elements.value: As a result, the UN Convention on Biological Diversity, the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (Target 15.8), as well as the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands (Target 4 under Strategic Goal 1), have all recognized the importance of preventing the introduction of IAS and managing their impacts.

The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development has set Target #15.8 specifically on IAS:
“By 2020, introduce measures to prevent the introduction and significantly reduce the impact of invasive alien species on land and water ecosystems and control or eradicate the priority species”.
Who or what are these threatening guests?

credit.footer: Ten examples of IAS present in the Mediterranean region (from left to right): hottentot fig (Carpobrotus edulis), yellow-bellied slider turtle (Trachemys scripta), coypu (Myocastor coypus), Adam’s needle (Yucca filamentosa), European carp (Cyprinus carpio), marsh frog (Rana ridibunda), giant reed (Arundo donax), small-flowered tamarix (Tamarix parviflora), Eucalyptus and tree of heaven (Ailanthus altissima). Photo credits at the end of the webstory.

elements.value: IUCN, International Union for Conservation of Nature, describes invasive alien species (IAS) as “animals, plants or other organisms introduced by man into places out of their natural range of distribution, where they become established and disperse, generating a negative impact on the local ecosystem and species.”

Their impact lies way beyond species extinction: the latest IPBES Global Assessment Report, identified IAS as one of the top five global culprits driving negative change in nature around the world – with numbers having risen by 70% since 1970 across 21 countries.
Invasive alien species curiosities
How to halt their spread?

credit.footer: Source: Wittenberg, R., Cock, M.J.W. (eds.) 2001. Invasive Alien Species: A Toolkit of Best Prevention and Management Practices. CAB International, Wallingford, Oxon, UK, xvii - 228.   Infographic: IUCN

elements.value:
Forewarned is forearmed
Controlling and eradicating most invasive species is problematic - almost impossible. Chemical and mechanical management options are often ineffective in the long-term, impractical, prohibitively costly, and even illegal. All factors considered, prevention remains the most cost-efficient approach.

Guiding principles for invasive alien species management, based on a ‘hierarchical approach’, call for prevention as the first line of defence. However, when prevention fails, early detection and rapid response are required, followed by eradication as the best option to manage established species, and finally permanent management when the other options are not applicable <sup>7</sup>.

Scientia potentia est
Detecting IAS, harmonizing, sharing and improving our knowledge about IAS taxa is mandatory to deliver a fast and effective response to the adverse situation which they may cause. Today several knowledge tools have been developed for this purpose:

• EICAT - Environmental Impact Classification of Alien Taxa: The Invasive Species Specialist Group within the IUCN Species Survival Commission has developed this global standard,which identifies and classifies alien species into five categories according to the magnitude of their detrimental impact. The EICAT standard facilitates comparisons but also predictions of the level of impacts across regions and taxonomic groups, thus helping to prioritize management actions and evaluate them at later stages.

• GRIIS - The Global Register of Introduced and Invasive Species: This global catalogue provides the first checklists of introduced (naturalised) and invasive species country-wise. Over 11,000 records of species are currently in the 20 sample countries alone, with environmental impact evidence for just over 20% of these.

On the other hand, the Ramsar Sites Information Service, an online resource with updated information on wetlands internationally recognized for their importance, facilitates key data provided by countries about IAS impacts to the wetlands worldwide.

Many Mediterranean wetlands are Ramsar Sites. They cover 185,000 km<sup>2</sup> in the region, which represents only between 1.7 and 2.4% of the total area of the 27 Mediterranean and peri-Mediterranean countries that are Parties to the Ramsar Convention, and around 1 to 2% of wetlands in the world.

info.title: Mediterranean Ramsar sites that have reported IAS as a threat

elements.value: The Ramsar Convention urges countries to identify, prevent, eradicate and control invasive alien wetland species. In the Mediterranean, several Parties to the Ramsar Convention are reporting IAS as a key threat for a number of important sites via the Ramsar Sites Information Service, as shown in this map with data as per November 2019.

Many more Ramsar sites are currently affected by IAS. The Ramsar Convention lacks specific provisions to stop current and prevent future expansion of IAS on its sites. Hence, getting more information is critical to obtain a better picture of the situation, which can be translated into actions on the ground.
Several initiatives are currently being developed in the Mediterranean to tackle IAS:

• INVASAQUA - Raising awareness in the Iberian Peninsula
    Prevention is key in the fight against IAS, and raising awareness about them is one of the key steps in that sense. The EU LIFE project INVASAQUA targets IAS in rivers, lakes and estuaries of Spain and Portugal that threaten the survival of native flora and fauna. A mix of activities (communication campaigns, museum exhibitions) and tools for early warning and rapid response (EWRR) are being developed with the aim to enhance the management of IAS in freshwater and estuarine habitats of the Iberian Peninsula, and raise public awareness about them. The IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation holds a key role in many activities of this project, and particularly in the implementation of the EICAT standard for freshwater invasives.

• Life ASAP – Raising awareness in Italy
    The project Life ASAP (Alien Species Awareness Program), co-financed by the European Commission, aims to increase awareness about IAS and promote their proper management in Italy, targeting a wide range of stakeholders and citizens: from protected areas and zoos staff to airport travelers, public institutions, science museums and schools. Citizen science events have been carried out throughout Italy with their project Smart App ASAP, and a quite successful itinerant laboratory for kids (Alien alarm!) has also been developed.

• MeRSiM-Network - Wetland managers: a key role on the ground
    Wetland managers are on the frontline to deal with IAS. Conscious of this reality, the Mediterranean Wetlands Initiative (MedWet) is building the Mediterranean Ramsar Site Managers Network (MeRSiM-Net), which aims to facilitate the exchange of knowledge, experiences and management practices in Mediterranean Ramsar Sites, and serve as a platform for mutual support in terms of technical advice and problem solving.

• Mobile app – Spot and stop an invasive species!
    The citizen science mobile application “Invasive Alien Species Europe”, developed by the Joint Research Centre of the European Commission, enables everyone to collect and share information on 49 Invasive Alien Species of interest in the European Union. Users can send the exact location of a sighting of an IAS and a photo via the app.

• Fighting mosquito infestations in Cyprus and Croatia
    The Center for Invasive Species (CIV) in Poreč, Croatia, identifies, maps, and monitors several IAS in the area of Poreč and Istria, including invasive mosquito species such as the tiger mosquito (Aedes albopictus). The CIV has produced a wide range of raising awareness activities and conservation tools, such as interactive online maps showing the main mosquito breeding sites.

    On the other hand,several institutions are leading activities in the Lake Akrotiri in Cyprus, one of the most important wetlands in Eastern Mediterranean due to its function as bird migration stopover, particularly for flamingos. This Ramsar site hosts projects that monitor interactions of IAS with local species, such as mosquitos and non-native mosquitofish, and also pollinating insects and non-native plants.

cover.title: The legacy of the land
cover.subtitle: Biodiversity in the Mediterranean agricultural landscapes

elements.value: Cereals, vegetables, citrus fruits, olive orchards and vines. The fertile grounds of the Mediterranean have been harvested for centuries, feeding civilisations, shaping landscapes, cultures and societies. With their practices, farmers, shepherds  and fishermen have built agricultural wisdom across generations, influencing the unique biodiversity of the Mediterranean region.

Today, the Mediterranean is under intense pressure from a variety of human activities and has become a priority for conservation. Mediterranean biodiversity is being lost at an unprecedented rate, and one of the primary drivers of this decline, particularly in terrestrial environments, is known to be agriculture . However, could agriculture also be part of the solution?
An inextricable bond

“Biodiversity is the basis of agriculture”
UN Convention on Biological Diversityii

If biodiversity thrives, so does agriculture: Biodiversity generates multiple ecosystem services - the direct and indirect benefits that people obtain from ecosystems - of which agriculture, as many other fields, is reliant upon. Biodiversity is the source of all crops and domesticated livestock, as well as, the varieties within them.

credit.footer: Soil biodiversity is also essential for farming systems.iii Photo by Markus Spiske on Unsplash

elements.value: From vertebrates to microorganisms,agricultural landscapes hold a tremendous range of species that have a profound and positive impact on Earth’s habitability.<sup>iv</sup> Henceforth, sustainable and well-managed agriculture systems can actually play a key role in improving biodiversity conservation. We can see many examples of the potential of these practices today.

The agricultural landscapes of the Med are the legacy of thousands of years of farming, shepherding and fishing experience. This experience and knowledge has been continuously cultivated by the Mediterranean people who developed a myriad of species and crops for human consumption through adapting their practices to local environments, traditions and customs. These traditional practices have proved to achieve a balanced, sustainable productivity in harmony with nature, preserving species, ecosystems and genetic diversity.

It is worth mentioning, that in the Mediterranean there are also countless cultural and sustainable practices with structural elements such as field margins, hedgerows, stonewalls, patches of woodland or scrub and small rivers which enhance biodiversity. However, the relationships between biodiversity, practice, and structural elements still needs to be further explored and documented.
Curiosities
The threat and the opportunity

Nowadays, agricultural landscapes are evolving in two opposite directions: abandonment or intensification. Traditional farming practices are giving way to a more profitable, intensive agriculture, which is provoking the loss of biodiversity thrived in these landscapes.

credit.footer: Some facts and figures regarding the loss of genetic diversity and the decline of species related to agriculture nowadays. Infographic: IUCN. Source: FAO(2018)<sup>v</sup>

elements.value: In the Mediterranean basin, as in many other parts of the world, the lack of crop diversity is quite concerning: over 85% of the total agricultural production focuses only on cereals, vegetables, and citrus fruitsvi. As the following map shows, olive orchards and vines are also important crops.

credit.footer: Source: GRID-Arendal

elements.value: All in all, the current trends are reducing the resilience of agricultural systems to adapt to variations, causing instability. In addition, they are threatening numerous wild species of plants and animals that depend on agrosilvopastoral practices in different ways, in an often complex and multidirectional relation.

credit.footer: Transhumance, a practice of moving livestock from one grazing ground to another in a seasonal cycle, typically to lowlands in winter and highlands in summer. Considered a form of pastoralism, this traditional practice, currently threatened, brings many benefits to agricultural landscapesvii. Photo by Alberto Bigoni on Unsplash

elements.value: A pledge for a more holistic approach

The benefits and values that healthy ecosystems and biodiversity provide are countless. This bond is particularly present in agricultural landscapes, but not always apparent. Agricultural productivity is typically measured by yield per hectare, a simplistic metric that does not account for the costs to our health, livelihoods, soils, water and climateviii. According to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity, “the precise link between diversity and the capacity of an ecosystem to provide services is a complex one, and an area in which science is still developing.” Some initiatives, like The Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity for Agriculture and Food (TEEBAgriFood), are focusing on making these benefits more visible and demonstrating their value in economic terms.

With 10 billion people to feed by 2050 and 40 percent of available land already growing foodix, new frameworks and models are very much needed to rethink the way food arrives on our plates. Sustainable, traditional agricultural practices may contribute to shine a light on the positive linkages of food systems to the environment and society.

When managed sustainably and knowledgeably, biodiversity provides the necessary resources for agriculture to thrive while having a minimal negative impact on the environmentx. Many traditional practices have proved to be sustainable benefiting biodiversity at a large and the Mediterranean basin offers many examples of it. Unfortunately, this invaluable heritage is being lost for different social and economic reasons, often influenced by lower productivity and profitability. To stop the loss of these practices, it is decisive to recognize the benefits they provide, and develop mechanisms to enhance them.

This map includes a compilation of different scientific papers documenting agricultural practices in the Mediterranean region that benefit different species of fauna and flora at three different levels: plot, farm and landscape. It is important to highlight that applying one specific practice is not enough to increase the associated biodiversity, as the agroecosystems are complex and interlinked in many different ways.
Plot level: Practices affecting mostly species with low mobility. Here, maintaining ground cover has proven to benefit biodiversity.
Farm level:Practices that include structural elements, like stonewalls, dead standing trees, solitary trees or field margins. Some of the practices at farm level benefit some species but harm others.
Landscape level: Some species of birds or bats only benefit from heterogeneous landscapes, as these articles describe.
Special sites: Places were many practices are being performed simultaneously or are working to better understand the link between practices and biodiversity.

“Good governance, enabling frameworks, and stewardship incentives are needed to facilitate mainstreaming of biodiversity.”
The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO)xi

The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) has also been very active mainstreaming biodiversity across sectors of agriculture: launching a Biodiversity Mainstreaming Platform, spreading awareness and mobilizing resources. The recent FAO strategy on mainstreaming biodiversity , approved in 2019, is the result of several regional dialogues with key stakeholders, and constitutes a significant effort to gather key knowledge to catalyse actions on this subject.

The Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN-Med) is in the process of developing a new strategic line of work, which will aim to enable positive feedbacks between agriculture and biodiversity, and to ensure that practitioners receive sufficient socio-economic support to maintain the positive practices for biodiversity.

The MAVA Foundation - a major funding partner of conservation projects - has created a programme to promote “cultural practices that shape the cultural landscapes which in turn, harbour biodiversity and preserve natural capital” in the Mediterranean Basin. IUCN-Med participates in this programme with several partners, developing actions that will improve the knowledge and monitoring of biodiversity. Activities are held mainly in five pilot landscapes: the Moroccan High Atlas, the Island of Lemnos in Greece, agricultural terraces in the Lebanese Al-Shouf Cedar Nature Reserve, grazing pastures of Portugal (Montados) and Spain (Dehesas), and the island of Menorca in Spain. This programme will also provide more examples of agricultural practices benefiting biodiversity across the Mediterranean region.
